Funds Disbursed from Assisted Reproduction Technology (ART) Treatment Co-funding Scheme

(Effectiveness of the Scheme)

1 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Health (a) how many couples have benefitted from the Assisted Reproduction Technology (ART) co-funding scheme for in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) since its inception in August 2008; (b) what is the total amount of funds disbursed; and (c) what is the success rate thus far.

The Minister of State for Health (Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan) (for the Minister for Health) : Sir, the Assisted Reproduction Technology (ART) treatment co-funding scheme was introduced to help make ART treatments, such as in-vitro fertilisation (IVF), more affordable for couples who have difficulty conceiving. Since the scheme's inception in August 2008, Ministry of Health (MOH) has subsidised a total of 5,503 ART treatment cycles, benefiting 3,841 couples in the process. Thus far, MOH has disbursed around $13 million in funding for this scheme. We are encouraged by the effectiveness of this scheme. About 26% of the treatment cycles under this scheme successfully resulted in live births, which compares well with the national average of 22%.

Page: 1568

Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Nee Soon) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Minister of State for the answer. In her reply, the Minister of State said that MOH subsidises about 3,000 couples for this particular scheme. I would like to ask the Minister of State, first, is this a subsidy given, because from what I understand, all patients going through IVF are considered "private patients" and no Government subsidy is entitled? My next supplementary question is that since the success rate is so good, will the Government consider extending this particular programme, because I understand that the grant is only available to couples who are receiving IVF treatment in Government restructured hospitals only? Will that be reviewed and can that be extended to the private hospitals, given that it is a grant and not a subsidy?

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan : Sir, the Member is right to say that it is not a healthcare subsidy per se. The ART co-funding scheme was introduced as part of the Marriage and Parenthood package to allow couples who have difficulties conceiving to go for ART treatment and make it more affordable for them. ART treatment is not essential to the patient's health and so it is a non-standard form of treatment. Like all non-standard treatment, there is no healthcare subsidy. So, if the patients go to a public hospital for ART treatment, if they are not under this co-funding scheme, they will be treated as private patients and charged private rates. So, the Member is right. But if they qualify under this co-funding scheme, then they will get subsidy under the co-funding scheme. When we implemented this, we did not extend it to the private hospitals because the scheme was new. We will continue to monitor demand and consider this as an option as we review our experience, but currently we are not thinking of extending it beyond the public sector as yet.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak : Thank you, Mr Speaker. My last question. I would like to thank the Minister of State for agreeing to review it with a view that it may be introduced to the private hospitals. I would like to ask the Minister of State when MOH compares the average success rate of 22% at the national level versus 26% for this particular programme, is there any factor that causes the success rate to be higher compared to the national level? From what I understand, patients going through this programme have to be below a certain age limit, and have to meet other governing criteria. In fact, a lot of couples unable to fit the criteria have no choice but to resort to going to the private hospitals to receive treatment. I am not sure if MOH would agree that the age difference may have contributed to the difference in success rate. Will MOH now relook at the data to see if when the patients are equal in terms of criteria, the success rates would be the same between the Government hospitals and private hospitals?

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan : Sir, the statistics that I quoted, that is, 26% under the co-funding scheme as compared to the national level average of 22% – are based on the same age profile. So, in fact, our 26% is also better compared internationally to, say, Australia and New Zealand for the same age profile, where it is about 22.3%. Yes, the Member is right that there are qualifying criteria for patients to go under this scheme. Age is one criterion. The patient has to be below 40 years old. There are certain clinical considerations too. That would likely have contributed to the higher success rate. Clinical evidence is that there is a higher success rate for patients below 40 years old. We need to impose conditions because we are subsidising using taxpayers' money. So, we need to ensure that it is effectively used.

Mr Low Thia Khiang (Aljunied) : Sir, a supplementary question. I would like to ask the Minister of State this: besides the age criterion, what are the other criteria to qualify for this co-funding scheme?

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan : The criteria will be that the patient has no more than one living child with her husband; the patient must be below 40 years of age at the start of the cycle; the patient has been assessed by the doctor to meet the clinical requirements for ART; treatment is a fresh cycle; no more than two embryos are transferred during the cycle; the patient has not already received three co-funded cycles in the past. The ART co-funding scheme is up to a maximum of three cycles. And the patient or her spouse must be a Singapore citizen at the start of the cycle.

Sir, I just wish to add to Member Dr Lim Wee Kiak's comment earlier about patients going to private sector hospitals if they are not under this scheme. They can actually go to the public sector and, obviously, there will be a range in the fees.

Debate on Annual Budget Statement

Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [17 February 2012],

"That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1 April 2012 to 31 March 2013." – [Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].

Question again proposed.

Ms Tan Su Shan (Nominated Member) : Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to speak. Allow me to declare my pecuniary interest as a banker. I would like to begin by congratulating the Deputy Prime Minister for delivering a Budget for a more inclusive and stronger Singapore. I am also heartened that the Budget appealed to our younger Singaporeans, many of whom care about our elderly, our poor and our disadvantaged, as we all should.

That said, the Deputy Prime Minister's stated goal is a Budget for the future. A Budget for the future should address the long-term issues faced by Singaporeans. A Budget for the future should perhaps relook or adapt to a different economic model to fuel our future growth. The growth model that propelled us for the past 10 years has worked well but reached its limits. We have been successful in attracting MNCs to Singapore, in building high-end manufacturing, and a vibrant services sector, and tourism.

But these successes have led to a reliance on foreign labour and caused a significant jump in our population. And this in turn has tested the limits of our domestic resources like transport, housing and healthcare. This is not sustainable. For the next 10 years, we need to look for growth that will not add so much to our already highly-stressed domestic resource pool. The kind of growth that will not lead to spiralling inflation, a widening income gap, or an over reliance on foreign labour. This may mean that we look for growth beyond Singapore's shores. This may mean that in the long term, we need to re-sharpen or retool ourselves for a different economic growth model.

Page: 1570

So, today, I want to offer three key issues to focus on: (i) inflation and how the high cost of living is impacting our business competiveness and how perhaps a fresh look at our existing monetary policy could address this; (ii) the sustainability of Singapore businesses, especially at the international level; and (iii) the building of our human capital with our education system becoming more innovative to keep us all ahead.

Let us begin with inflation and monetary policy. It is obvious that Singapore is becoming an increasingly expensive city in which to live and to operate in. Last Friday, we saw our Consumer Price Index (CPI) going up 4.8% and core inflation was a three-year high of 3.5%. This reflects a serious build up of underlying cost pressures. Let us not forget that CPI represents a "change", or a delta. So when the previous figure was already high, then our costs get higher each month and each year.

In 2011, the CPI was at a high of 5.2% and that was more than five times the median of the 1.0% in the prior decade. Rising inflation hurts our businesses, especially SMEs who are already operating on low single digit margins. High inflation is passed onto consumers, and reduces our purchasing power, with our retirees one of the worst affected. With the new Budget measures pushing labour costs higher, whilst doing not much to address the key challenges of high rental and housing costs, core inflation will likely remain high this year. Is this the "new normal"? Are we asking our consumers and business community to accept that rising prices are here to stay?

Whilst the MAS has continued to maintain its strong Singapore dollar (SGD) appreciation stance, and this has helped keep imported inflation at bay, it is domestic inflation that is the greater threat. Key drivers of domestic inflation are increases in rentals, wages and COE costs. These are demand-side driven inflation pressures that may require some supply-side measures to counter them. An inclusive Budget should target and hold down domestic inflation. Having a strong SGD policy may not be enough. Perhaps at this point, we may want to think about adapting our monetary policy for a mature economy like ours, focusing on managing our nominal effective exchange rate (NEER) may not be sufficient. We may need to start to focus on other variables, including interest rates and money supply.

Two, business sustainability and internationalisation. It does appear that the Budget seeks to encourage Singapore businesses to venture offshore, be it to tap lower cost facilities and labour or new sources of revenue growth. Whilst this is to be applauded, the facts are not encouraging, especially for SMEs. The National Business Survey for 2011, conducted by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF), showed that businesses are actually looking to scale down their overseas expansion in 2012. The number of companies with an overseas presence has already dropped from 75% to 56%. The main sectors with the biggest drop are: manufacturing -23%; construction and real estate -20%; and trading -10%.

Why? Competition, manpower issues and unclear rules and regulations were cited as key reasons. The volatility of the SGD has not helped either. The SME Development Survey 2011 shows that foreign currency exchange loss is the key challenge for 43% of SMEs. And here is why – there was an 11% spike in the volatility of the SGD, with the standard deviation of the SGD/USD increasing to 0.086 over the last four years, versus 0.077 in the four years before. This spike in volatility has clearly made hedging costs for exporters very high. Furthermore, a continued appreciation of the SGD nominal effective exchange rate, means that overseas profits when repatriated back to Singapore, are worth less in SGD, again compressing margins. Hence, a Budget for the future may need to address some of these challenges faced by local companies as they venture abroad, especially SMEs.

Three, education. Let us now talk about education and the grooming of our future talent. This is my final point, and as I had started on a good note, I too want to end on a good note. Education is a sector in which the Singapore Government has done well in the last decades. Now that we've been recognised as one of the world's best, what is next? The Chinese have a saying:长 江 后 浪 推 前 浪, 人 不 进 则 退. As we reach our goals, we need to aim higher. That does not mean better scores or grades. At this juncture, we want our children to stay relevant, to stay ahead. And I think we need to purposefully test some new models and new solutions that will better prepare our children for a more complex, inter-connected world. If we are to face a new economic growth model based on innovative thinking and collaborative action, then the old linear way of thinking is no longer sufficient.

At this point, allow me to introduce the House to the Collage Method, a non-linear method of learning that has just been piloted in Singapore. My family actually experienced the Collage model of learning first-hand as my son's school had a team of very brave, forward-thinking teachers, and my son, when he was in Primary 3, was fortunate enough to be picked as a guinea pig. As a mother, I was delighted with the Collage experience and I really hope that more can benefit from it.

So, what is Collage? It is about collaborative teaching and learning. It is about the intertwining of different disciplines, helping children to think for themselves. And it is this connectivity of ideas that make a big difference. Let me share with Members an example where the children were asked to make kites. As they made kites, they learnt Math – angles and triangles. And then they painted the designs on their kites and they learnt art. And the fun part was when they were taken to the park to fly the kites, they saw science in motion. They realised that the faster they ran, the higher the kites flew. Hence, they learnt all about kinetic energy. Then they came back to the class and learnt how to do a presentation on the history of kites 风筝的历史 in Chinese, where they picked up Powerpoint and Chinese Google. They even learnt to make a movie on the kites! And the best part? They all loved going to school and they developed a love for learning that will stay with them for the rest of their life.

So, whilst the Primary Education Review and Implementation (PERI) system has focused pretty much on the hardware of our primary school system, for our future, why not focus on the software? I hope that by sharing Collage, we can plant the seed to encourage our teachers and parents to adopt such teaching methods where students' learning styles are respected and they are taught to innovate and collaborate at a young age. Yesterday, Ms Indranee Rajah cited a great example of how public-sector productivity could have been improved if only each agency collaborated more with one another. Perhaps, the Collage style of training could be adapted for the public sector too. I can understand the resource constraints faced by the MOE but if the MOE would consider the merits of a Collage model and enable more of our students to benefit from it – even if the initial steps are modest – I am sure our young will benefit greatly.

Sir, we are a small island, 700 square km, which we have expanded through ingenuity, hard work and vision. Thankfully, today, our reserves allow us to spread our wings and invest in far flung countries, and bring home the gains to fund our public expenditure each year. And, yet, we need to do more to ensure that this investment income is not our only source of income. To do so, we need a new model of growth, without all the negative issues that we have seen built up over the last five years. So, whilst we are a small island, we have big dreams, and as we sit on the cusps of big structural change, we need a Budget and a Government to turn these dreams into reality.

Sir, as this House debates an inclusive Budget for all Singaporeans, I hope it will also address some of the long-term challenges we face and help us focus on key issues and the key drivers of our long-term goals – for our businesses, our people and our next generation. Sir, I support the Budget.

Are our Government policies contributing to it? We have been asking Singaporeans to look at the bigger picture. I think it is also timely for the Government to look at the bigger picture. I must declare my interest as an engineer in the construction sector, the industry that I am most familiar with. We have been building MRT projects for the last 20-30 years. Besides spending money on getting the infrastructure, did we put in deliberate efforts to also build up the capability of local expertise? LTA has been too occupied to build the rail network at the cheapest possible cost and, in the process, they brought in a lot of foreign contractors. We keep complaining that locals are reluctant to be in construction and engineering. But look at the way HDB is calling tenders for consultancy works. I have calculated and it is not even enough to pay our engineers adequately. I am sure the intense competition will have an adverse long-term repercussion on the profession. I am not surprised if more will exit this profession.

We cannot live on passion for a profession alone. Every time we give feedback, the standard answer is, "MOF policy." In recent years, the construction sector needs more manpower and resources to cope with the demand for BTO flats. If the construction companies are incapable of achieving the required productivity in a short period of time, future BTO construction projects may experience delay or, worse, suffer from inferior workmanship. So, please do R and R – review and reflect.

Moving on to transport, I am sure there is unanimous agreement that a world-class public transport system contributes to an inclusive society. An efficient transport system ensures that everyone gets around safely and punctually, never mind if they do not have cars or taxis. As our population has ballooned by more than a million in a mere short span of a few years, it is imperative that we constantly review our public transport system to ensure that it is able to meet increased demands without sacrificing efficiency and safety.

SMRT has a fleet of 800 buses plying 74 routes, while SBS Transit has 3,000 buses which it said covers 75% of the scheduled bus service market share. This sheer numbers should rightly translate to better connectivity for residents to their destinations in good time. However, I say "rightly" because this does not seem to be the case. In Nee Soon South, residents are telling me that they are spending up to half an hour getting around the neighbourhood to the key amenities, to the MRT stations, because the waiting times for feeder bus services are too long.

Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, we come to the issue of why the Government is taking the extraordinary step of spending $1.1 billion over 10 years to increase bus capacity.

Several Members have asked about this, including Dr Amy Khor, Mr Seng Han Thong, Mr Lim Biow Chuan and Mr Pritam Singh. There are, in particular, questions on whether this is a subsidy to the transport operators and their shareholders.

The Government considered its investment to expand bus capacity very carefully. This was not a normal budgetary decision. It is an important step, to reduce waiting times and crowdedness that Singaporeans experience daily as they take public buses.

Let me start by explaining what the Public Transport Operators (PTOs) themselves are responsible for. The PTOs are required to expand their fleets, their bus fleets to cater to the growth in passenger numbers, as well as to ensure that they meet the service levels that are mandated under the existing regulatory framework. This is why, in addition to operating the existing bus fleet of about 4,000 buses, they will have to buy 250 additional buses to achieve this; and they will fund this on their own.

The Government is putting $1.1 billion into the bus system in order to step up bus service levels beyond the current service standards that are required of the PTOs.

It will increase bus capacity on existing heavily-utilised routes making them less crowded and giving commuters a more pleasant journey.

Almost all feeder buses will run every 10 minutes or less – for two hours in the morning, and the evening, two-hour peak periods instead of the one-hour peak period under the current service level requirements.

Commuters on existing routes will thus benefit both from shorter waiting times and less crowded bus journeys.

And a number of new bus services, in addition to existing bus services, will be added to improve connectivity, and provide commuters with more public transport choices.

Page: 1615

So these are improvements that commuters have been hoping for and waiting for.

As a condition for the Government's investment, the PTOs will have to deliver on these service level improvements, which go beyond existing regulatory requirements.

We cannot simply mandate that the PTOs add these 550 buses to improve service levels. First, because it goes significantly beyond the current service levels in the current regulatory framework. Second, the PTOs' bus operations are already running operating losses, and the 550 additional buses, in particular, are projected to be a loss-making operation. The cost of acquiring and running the 550 buses is beyond what can be recovered from revenues in running the buses.

Take the example of improving the frequency of feeder bus services. Increasing the number of buses to make this possible will shorten waiting times but will add little to revenues, since the total number of passengers taking the service will remain largely the same. So, more buses, more drivers, more fuel but no similar increase in revenues because it is essentially the same pool of passengers. They now have to wait shorter times and enjoy less crowded journeys, but it is essentially the same pool.

Without the Government stepping in, these significant service level improvements would only have been achievable if fares have been raised sharply. The 550 additional buses mean significantly higher costs – not only to purchase the buses, but also because more than 1,000 drivers would need to be hired and paid a good wage, as Mr Seng Han Thong and NMP Mary Liew have pointed out. Fare revenues of the PTOs would have had to go up by about 12% to 13% – which translates into an increase in passenger fares of about 15 cents per journey – if the PTOs had to achieve this on their own. How much is 12% to 13%? In the last five years since 2006, fares went up by 0.3%. So, 12% to 13% is quite a significant leap compared to what we have seen in the last five years. That would have been the only way which we could have achieved these service level improvements if the Government had not stepped in.

Hence, the reality of the matter is that the $1.1 billion Government package, or $110 million per year, is a subsidy for public transport commuters, and not a subsidy for the PTOs. It will improve service levels for commuters, not the profits of the PTOs.

The $1.1 billion package is expected to cover the losses on the 550 buses – in other words, the additional costs, net of revenues. Of the $1.1 billion package, $280 million is budgeted for the purchase of the 550 buses over the next five years, and $820 million to cover the net operating costs over the 10 years. This is based on the best estimates currently. However, we will be monitoring and scrutinising the PTOs' actual costs for both the purchase and running of the buses. Should their losses turn out to be lower than expected, the Government funding will be reduced correspondingly. So, one way or another, there are no profits to be made from the 550 buses.

The $1.1 billion for additional buses complements the $60 billion we are putting into the expansion of the rail system. It will take several years for these new rail lines to come on stream or all of them to come on stream. That is why we are stepping in now to add bus capacity and quickly improve the daily experience of commuters. It is what commuters want, and we have assessed that it is worth the public investment. Mr Alex Yam, Dr Intan Azura and Mr Hawazi Daipi asked about youth gangs and youth offending. Between 2007 and 2010, the number of youth arrests remained stable at about 4,000 per year, and in fact decreased to 3,450 arrests in 2011. The most common crimes committed were shop theft or about 28%, and rioting or about 12%. Specifically, the number of youths arrested for rioting, which can broadly be used as a proxy of youth gang violence, also decreased from 531 arrests in 2010 to 399 in 2011. Overall, 84% of the youths arrested were aged between 14 and 19 years old, and the majority of them were students.

The public was understandably concerned with specific incidents of youth-related violence in the last two years. Although these cases alone do not suggest that our youth crime situation or youth gang situation is worsening, it is important that we send a strong message that brazen acts of violence and intimidation will not be condoned. Police will not hesitate to take offenders to task, and prevent young people from getting deeper into a life of crime.

The Working Group on Youth Gangs (WGYG) was formed in December 2010. Based on its recommendations, I announced a slew of measures in November last year, covering greater investment in diversion and rehabilitation, increased co-ordination amongst stakeholder agencies, and enhanced anti-gang legislation to disrupt youth gangs. As we tackle issues around youth gangs, there are other evolving youth-related issues that we face. For example, Second Minister Iswaran had spoken about the increasing number of youths arrested for offences related to unlicensed moneylending (UML) and I will touch on it later. We are also beginning to see an increasing number of young drug abusers arrested.

To ensure that we have in place effective structures to tackle youth crime, Police has established the Youth Offenders Unit, effective 1 March 2012. The Youth Offenders Unit will coordinate and drive youth crime-related policies and programmes with partner agencies, and monitor trends on youth offending. The Unit will also oversee public education and outreach efforts to youth. The new Unit will enable Police to pull together holistically its strategies, policies and programmes on youth offending and youth crime.

Today, youths who are arrested are sent for appropriate intervention programmes. These range from pre-court diversionary programmes such as the Guidance Programme, to Court-ordered options such as probation and residential rehabilitation in the Juvenile Homes, to sentencing at the Reformative Training Centre (RTC), and ultimately also Prisons.

At the RTC and Prisons, youth offenders are placed on programmes, including certified skills training courses and psychological intervention programmes, to address their anti-social thinking and attitudes towards violence. In addition, their families are involved in the rehabilitation process as we believe that strong family support is integral to their eventual reintegration back to the community.

Nonetheless, the Working Group on Youth Gangs believes that more can be done. About one in three youth offenders re-offend within two years of release from the RTC and Prisons. Youth offenders often present multiple risk factors, such as violence and anti-social thinking, which contribute to criminal behaviour. To address this, Prisons will be developing Specialised Treatment Programme (STP) modules to more effectively address these risk factors. Prisons will also continue to monitor the effectiveness of their psychological treatment programmes to ensure that they adhere to international standards, and share these with other correctional institutions.

The myriad of issues related to youth offending reflects the complexity of this problem, which cannot be resolved through structures and systems alone. Underpinning all these efforts is the recognition that families too play an important role in the life of our youths, and in the transmission of sound values to the next generation.

Beyond the family, we, as a community, all play a role, too. During my work in the WGYG, I met ex-gang members who had made the decision to turn their lives around, and there was one particularly memorable case. Mr Royston Khoo had joined a gang when he was only 13 years old. After being involved in various gang fights, he was eventually arrested at age 16, and was referred to the Streetwise Programme (SWP). During the programme, he went through counselling, group work sessions and community service. For Royston, the programme made him grow closer to his family and he began to realise how much hurt he had caused others. The desire to lead a more meaningful life led him to start volunteering at his SWP agency, Youth Guidance Outreach Services, at the age of 18. I am happy to say that he is now a full-time social worker there, successfully giving back to society. This shows how critical community support is in helping youth-at-risk reintegrate into society.

Mr Chairman, apart from youth crime, we also share Mr Hawazi Daipi and Dr Intan Azura's concerns about drug abuse among youths. Before going into the details, let me begin with the broader drug situation. Firstly, the global and regional trends. Drug use continues to be a serious global problem. On the supply side, drug traffickers and organised criminals form a complex web of transnational networks, fuelling a global criminal enterprise and escalating demand for drugs.

Closer to home, Southeast Asia has seen soaring production, trafficking and consumption of amphetamine-type stimulants, such as Ice and Ecstasy, and a resurgence in opium cultivation and heroin trafficking. In fact, from 2010 to 2011, seizures of heroin and methamphetamine or "Ice" by the Central Narcotics Bureau increased by 48% and 151% respectively.

Secondly, domestic trends. Such developments pose a serious threat to our stability and security. The drug abuse situation is an area of concern. Drug abusers arrested is on a rising trend, increasing from 2,537 abusers arrested in 2008 to 3,265 abusers arrested last year. Malays and Chinese made up the majority of those arrested last year, at 48% and 33% respectively. Of the arrests in 2011, repeat abusers made up two-thirds of those arrested and new abusers the remaining one-third. While the numbers are much lower compared to the peak of the drug problem in the 1970s, we should not be complacent, and instead take decisive action before the situation worsens.

Looking ahead, we are particularly concerned about the large number of about 3,000 repeat abusers expected to be released from Long-Term Imprisonment (LT) from 2012 to 2014. LT abusers are often more likely to relapse into drug abuse. Based on the 2009 cohort, the two-year relapse rate of LT abusers was 36%, compared to 24% for the overall cohort.

Their drug addiction not only harms them, and as Mr Hawazi inferred, inflicts pain on others as well. To feed this expensive habit, many repeat drug abusers turn to crime, including drug trafficking. Indeed, 79% of those in prison have a drug antecedent, and more than 95% of those in long-term imprisonment for drug consumption have some form of criminal antecedents. Thus, the large number of releases over the next few years could result in more arrests in the future as well. To address this, we have allocated additional manpower to CNB and the Prison Service to step up supervision and aftercare of those being released from long-term imprisonment.

On young abusers, we share Mr Hawazi's concern that repeat abusers pose the danger of contaminating others within society. Given repeat drug abusers' close networks with drug suppliers and other drug abusers in Singapore, they can easily influence others, especially young and vulnerable persons, to experiment with drugs.

To address this, CNB recently modified reporting arrangements for all young drug and inhalant supervisees. Previously, all supervisees, regardless of age, reported at the Police Land Division closest to their homes. As of 1 January 2012, CNB's Supervision Division at the Police Cantonment Complex has been converted to a dedicated Young Persons Reporting Centre, with all supervisees aged 21 years and below reporting there. With this change, we aim to reduce opportunities for young supervisees to be influenced by older and more experienced drug abusers, and by each other.

Having said this, the number of youths below 20 years of age, arrested for drug abuse, has shown a steady upward trend in the past five years, increasing from 79 in 2007 to 257 in 2011, as noted by Dr Intan. About 30% of these youths were students. Many first-time youth abusers use drugs to cope with problems, or take drugs "for fun".

We are concerned about the changing attitudes amongst the young, and the perception that taking "party drugs" is an acceptable lifestyle. Our worry is that synthetic drugs have increasingly become a common option for young drug abusers. Among youth abusers arrested in 2011, 65% had abused methamphetamine, or commonly known as "Ice". Amphetamine-type stimulants, such as Ecstasy and Ice are highly addictive, and can lead to psychiatric disorders where abusers may hallucinate or become violent. Indeed, the abuse of Ice has toxic effects and will cause extensive damage to the brain.

Currently, first and second-time arrested abusers may be admitted to Drug Rehabilitation Centres (DRCs) to undergo treatment programmes based on their assessed risks and needs. Programme evaluation has shown positive results in changing participants' attitudes towards drug abuse. Besides raising their awareness on the dangers of substance abuse, the programmes also equip them with coping strategies to address possible triggers for relapse upon their release. Our stand on drugs is clear. Drug use is harmful and undesirable. Thus, we operate a zero-tolerance policy on drugs and aim to prevent harm through preventive education, tough laws, vigorous enforcement, treatment and rehabilitation, as well as aftercare to help integrate ex-abusers back into society.

Given the worsening regional drug situation and the growing number of drug abusers in Singapore, the Taskforce on Drugs was set up in October last year. The Taskforce aims to take a deeper look at issues related to prevention, rehabilitation, as well as supporting legislative and process reviews. These will include measures to address the growing number of youth abusers, an issue which both Dr Intan and Mr Hawazi have expressed and are concerned about. Sir, we recognise that helping inmates transit from incarceration to reintegration within the community is important. The Committee on the Prevention of Re-Offending (CPR) was established in 2009 to study and propose recommendations to address the problem of re-offending. One of the key recommendations was to develop a more structured aftercare scheme with greater scaffolding, tighter supervision and enhanced community support. Ms Indranee asked if the Ministry will be more flexible in granting Long-Term Visit Passes for foreign spouses of Singaporeans with past criminal records. We are cognisant of the latter's needs, but we are mindful that should a marriage not work out or the husband reoffends, the spouse who is a foreigner will not have relatives in Singapore to turn to nor jobs to sustain herself or her children as many are generally low skilled. ICA, therefore, evaluates every application for a Long-Term Visit Pass carefully, based on a variety of factors, such as the sponsor's ability to financially support the family and sustain the marriage, whether there are Singapore Citizen children from the marriage, and duration of the marriage.

Over the last five years, 11,500 foreign spouses of Singaporeans were granted Long-Term Visit Passes annually. This represents a success rate of 85% over the applications received, and includes applications from those who have had criminal records before, but had qualified. But for ex-offenders who demonstrate a strong commitment to keep a clean record and remain in stable employment, we will review how we can better facilitate such applications and help these families.
